div1.p: Wood acknowledges a letter from Kean, and expresses the hope that he, Kean, and Dorey have provided information to Sullivan that will help to clarify a subject on which he is working. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 7, 1925
div1.opener:
Office of the Governor-General
Manila
December 7, 1925.
Dear Kean:
div1.p:
Your letter of November 6th with memo-
randum received. It will be of the greatest value
in keeping my records. I thank you very much for
it. This is only a line of acknowledgment. I ap-
preciate the way you have handled the matter. I
hope Sullivan has seen you before this. The memo-
randum I sent him and one sent by Dorey supplemented
by your memorandum will put him thoroughly straight
on the subject.

Mrs. Wood joins me in warmest regards
and every best wish for you and Mrs. Kean for a
Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.
div1.closer:
As ever,
Faithfully yours, Leonard Wood Col. Jefferson R. Kean,
Army Medical Museum and Library,
7th and B Streets,
Washington, D.C.
